# What is Binary?

We've all heard that computers do everything in numbers or everything in ones and zeros. 
I'm looking at my editor (vim) and honestly, it doesn't look like a bunch of numbers, just words. 
What then does this mean? How can things like text be 'numbers' under the hood?

## Bases of Numbers

When we count, we have a concept of digits. 
There are ten symbols (0-9) and when we get to the end of them, we represent the number with *two* such symbols.
The first symbol is the 'tens' and the second is the 'ones.'
You know this&mdash;if you're a human in the twenty-first century then you probably use numbers greater than ten on a daily basis&mdash;so why am I telling you this?
Well there's nothing particularly special about the number ten.
We could count with twelve symbols and increment on the twelfth. 
Base twelve would be [much more convenient](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U6xJfP7-HCc) than base ten, at least when doing math in one's head.

The generic formula for converting an integer from one base to another is:

x<sub>n</sub> represents each digit of the number, starting with the rightmost, and b represents the base.

So let's use this formula. 
We'll start with 384 (base 10).

<div class="math"><img src='data:image/svg+xml;base64,'/></div>
%%
  4 * 10^0 
+ 8 * 10^1 
+ 3 * 10^2 
=
300 + 80 + 4
=
384

%%
\begin{align}
4\: \times &\:10^0\\
+ 8\: \times &\:10^1\\
+ 3\: \times &\:10^2\\
\hline
=\:\:\:\:\: &\:\:\:\:4\\
+\:\:\:\:\:\: &\:\:80\\
+\:\:\:\:\:\: &300\\
\hline
=\:\:\:\:\: &384
\end{align}
%%

Now 234 (base 8).

<div class="math"><img src='data:image/svg+xml;base64,'/></div>
%%
  4 * 8^0
+ 3 * 8^1
+ 2 * 8^2
=
128 + 24 + 4
=
156
%%
%%
\begin{align}
&4 \times 8^0\\
+ &3 \times 8^1\\
+ &2 \times 8^2\\
\hline
= &4 + 24 + 128\\
= &156
\end{align}
%%

Finally 01100101 (base 2).

<div class="math"><img src='data:image/svg+xml;base64,'/></div>

%%
  1 * 2^0
+ 0 * 2^1
+ 1 * 2^2
+ 0 * 2^3
+ 0 * 2^4
+ 1 * 2^5
+ 1 * 2^6
+ 0 * 2^7
=
64 + 32 + 4 + 1
=

%%
%%
\begin{align}
&1 \times 2^0\\
+ &0 \times 2^1\\
+ &1 \times 2^2\\
+ &0 \times 2^3\\
+ &0 \times 2^4\\
+ &1 \times 2^5\\
+ &1 \times 2^6\\
+ &0 \times 2^7\\
\hline
= &0 + 64 + 32 + 0\\
+ &0 + 4 + 0 + 1\\
= &101
\end{align}
%%

## So How Do Computers Store Numbers?

As you may have guessed, computers store numbers in binary&mdash;base 2. 
Binary is the most compact way to store numbers.
I know that sounds weird, because as we've just seen, a number like 101 in decimal is over twice as long in binary.
In decimal, each digit has to take up space in which at least 10 distinct permutations are possible. 
Binary is different&mdash;you only need to fit two possible permutations for each digit, meaning you can get it to fit in as small a space as you can signify 2 possibilities (like empty space or a dot).

Now there is one weird thing you may have noticed about that last equation.
The binary number had a `0` at the front. 
That zero doesn't give the number any additional meaning, so why is it there?
When computers store numbers, they store all the 'digits' in a line.
It'd be the equivalent of writing down the numbers `99`, `310`, and `1003` as `993101003`.
There's no way to tell where one value and another begins. 
The solution is to use set digit lengths. 
In the example above, we could make each number 4 digits long, storing them as `009903101003`.
Knowing the digit length, it's easy to tell that the values are `99`, `310`, and `1003`.
When numbers are stored by computers, they're likewise stored with set lengths.
While the lengths fluctuated in the early days of computers, they now almost universally use the size of 8 binary digits.
This grouping of 8 binary digits, or 'bits,' is called a 'byte.'

There's an obvious problem with the set length system; a maximum value. 
In the base 10 example, you can't store a number greater than `9999`&mdash;`10000` total values (including `0000`).
With the 8-bit byte, you can't store numbers greater than `255`&mdash;256 possibilities.
256 is an impractically small number to work with; to get more we have to use multiple bytes.
On most computers, the `int` type is 4 bytes (32 bits), with `4294967296` (256^4) possibilities. 
We never really escape the maximum value problem, only make the maximum large enough that it's not relevant. 

There's another problem though&mdash;negative numbers.
Unlike when we write numbers out, we can't just prepend our number with a negative sign; we only have 2 permutations, 0 and 1, and neither of them are a negative sign.
So I have bad news about our 429467296-possibility integer can't count to 429467295.
We have to make the first bit declare negative or positive. 
A 0 means positive, while 1 is negative. 
The positive numbers work like you'd expect them to; the integer now maxxing out at 2147483647 since the first bit can't be used to store the value.
Negative numbers are more interesting.
Rather than count down from 0 like we do, they count up from the minimum value of the number. 
-1 is when all the digits are 1&mdash;what would have been the maximum value if the digit were unsigned.
-2 is one less than the maximum value (i.e. 11111&hellip;110), and -3 one less than that (11111&hellip;101). 
Because of this system, normal addition and subtraction mechanics work the same way regardless of whether the number is signed or unsigned.

The only problem we have left is when we're *at* the maximum value and try to add one more. 
Theoretically, 01111&hellip;111 will become 10000&hellip;000, the *lowest* value possible (-2147483648 in the case of a 4 byte integer).
Luckily, a lot of modern programming languages will catch you when you try and exceed the maximum, throwing an error rather than converting to a negative number.

## So How Do Computers Store Other Things?

The short answer is that everything is a number.
Take this text. Every character has a specific number associated with it. 
T is 84, a is 97, k is 107, and so on. 
The computer just stores those numbers, but the program interpretting them knows that they're text and displays them on your screen.
Now you may be wondering why our standard length number is 8 bits; something impractically small for most math.
Well, all the characters on a standard American keyboard (plus the 32 control characters that aren't used any more but are still included in the set) don't add up to 256, which means an 8-bit byte is more than capable of storing a basic character.
The standard mappings of characters on your keyboard and the numbers they're stored as are known as 'ascii.'
If you google 'ascii table' you can find that listing. 
But we've got a problem; there's more than just American English, and sometimes you need some weird character like &#233; or a special symbol, like those emdashes I'm so fond of. 
If you add all those various symbols together, you get a number many *many* orders of magnitude greater than 256.
I'll skip over the details, but since most characters aren't special like that, they're stored as 8-bit. Then, after a certain size, the 8 bit number tells the program interpretting the text that it's actually 2 bytes (16 bits) long, thus doubleing the possibilities. 
Rinse and repeat, and you've got quite a large number of possibilites for characters without having to store every character with a high bit count.

What about colors? Well, one common way of storing colors is via RGB. 
Red, green, and blue make up the Positive Primary Colors, and you can get any color projected with light by combining different strength of red, green, and blue light.
To store a color in RGB, the computer stores a number for red, blue, and green. 
In a lot of cases a perfect hue isn't needed (we meatbags can't really tell the difference between 31% red and 31.01% red), so computers just store each color value as a single byte.
Have you ever used color hex codes? If you don't know what I'm talking about, that's fine, but when you're working with CSS and you need to specify a color, you use a hex code. It typically looks something like this: <span style="background-color:#ef8231;color:#000;">#ef8231</span>, which is a weird orangish color. 
Now, this is actually a set of three hexidecimal values with a maximum digit length of 2.
The 2 character maximum value for a hexidecimal number is&hellip; ff, or 255. 256 possibilities from 0 to ff, exactly one byte.

## Concluding Thoughts

I've skipped over a lot and oversimplified even more, but I hope this helps you understand what all is going on under the hood of your computer.
